Kirkwood-Buff Integral Analysis (picmol.kbi)¶

class picmol.kbi.KBI(prj_path: str, pure_component_path: str, rdf_dir: str = 'rdf_files', kbi_method: str = 'adj', rkbi_min=0.75, kbi_fig_dirname: str = 'kbi_analysis', avg_start_time=100, avg_end_time=None, solute_mol=None, geom_mean_pairs=[])[source]¶

Class for calculating Kirkwood-Buff Integrals from radial distribution functions in a GROMACS project

Parameters:

  • prj_path (str) – absolute path to project directory; contains subdirectories containing systems as a function of composition

  • pure_component_path (str) – absolute path to pure component directory; contains subdirectories of molecules at a given temperature

  • rdf_dir (str, optional) – directory name where RDF files are located in each system directory, default is rdf_files

  • kbi_method (str, optional) – correction method to apply to correlation function, default is adj

  • options (kbi_method) –

    • ‘raw’: no correction

    • ’adj’: correcting for tail of RDF \(\neq\) 1 at large r

    • ’gv’: correcting the number densities to account for excess/depletion, introduced by Ganguly and Van der Vegt

    • ’kgv’: applying a damping function introduced by Kruger to the correction function by Ganguly and Van der Vegt

  • rkbi_min (float or dict, optional) – fraction of r; lower bound for extrapolation to the thermodynamic limit, default is 0.75. float will be applied to all systems and dict uses systems as keys with corresponding float values.

  • kbi_fig_dirname (str, optional) – directory name for results from KBI analysis, default is kbi_analysis

  • avg_start_time (float, optional) – start time (ns) for property (temperature, volume, enthalpy) analysis from .edr file, default is 100

  • avg_end_time – end time (ns) for property (temperature, volume, enthalpy) analysis from .edr file, default is end of trajectory

  • solute_mol (str) – molecule name in .top file corresponding to molecule used to sort systems

  • geom_mean_pairs (list[list[molecule_ids]], optional) – pairs of molecules for taking the geometric mean of, default is empty list

run()[source]¶

Run KBI analysis and calculate activity coefficients and Gibbs thermodynamic properties

property T_sim¶
Returns:

average simulation temperature (K)

property unique_mols¶
Returns:

unique molecule names in .top file for the project

property num_comp¶
Returns:

number of components in project

property mol_nums_by_component¶
Returns:

dictionary of molecule numbers by component for each system, read from .top file

property total_num_mols¶
Returns:

dictionary of total number of molecules in each system, read from .top file

property properties_by_molid¶
Returns:

pandas DataFrame only for molecules present in project. Load molecular_properties.csv and set molecule name in .top file as index.

property molar_vol¶
Returns:

np.array of pure component molar volumes (cm3/mol), defaults to results from pure component simulations, if pure component simulation not found use value at STP from molecular_properties.csv

kbi_npt(r, g, r_lo, r_hi, avg, sys_num, mol_i, mol_j, method)[source]¶

For a given radial distribution function, calculate KBI from r_lo to r_hi by applying a correction to the correlation function.

Parameters:

  • r (np.array) – distance (nm) between two molecules in radial distribution function

  • g (np.array) – radial distribution function for two molecules as a function of r

  • r_lo (float) – minimum r (nm) to evaluate integral over

  • r_hi (float) – maximum r (nm) to evaluate integral over

  • avg (float) – average value of g as r -> R, i.e., average value of the tail of RDF

  • sys_num (int) – system index

  • mol_i (str) – molecule id in .top file for i in RDF, \(g_ij(r)\)

  • mol_j (str) – molecule id in .top file for j in RDF, \(g_ij(r)\)

  • method (str) – KBI correction method to implement

  • options (method) –

    • ‘raw’: no correction

    • ’adj’: correcting for tail of RDF != 1 at large r

    • ’gv’: correcting the number densities to account for excess/depletion, introduced by Ganguly and Van der Vegt

    • ’kgv’: applying a damping function introduced by Kruger to the correction function by Ganguly and Van der Vegt

Corrections to correlation function (\(h_{ij}(r)\)), where \(g_{ij}^{NpT}\) is the radial distribution function in NpT ensemble, \(N_j\) is the number of molecules of type j, \(\Delta N_{ij}\) is the number of molecules of type j around molecule i in radius of shell dr, and \(V\) is the volume of simulation box.

\[h_{ij}^{raw}(r) = g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) - 1\]
\[h_{ij}^{adj}(r) = g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) - avg\]
\[h_{ij}^{gv}(r) = g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) \left(\frac{N_j\left(1 - \frac{4/3 \pi r^3}{V} \right)}{N_j \left(1 - \frac{4/3 \pi r^3}{V} \right) - \Delta N_{ij} - \delta_{ij}} \right) - 1\]
\[\Delta N_{ij} = \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 \rho_j \left(g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) - 1\right) dr\]
\[h_{ij}^{kgv}(r) = h_{ij}^{gv} \left(1 - \frac{3r}{2R} + \frac{r^3}{2r^3} \right)\]

KBI (\(G_{ij}^R\)) calculations from corrected correlation functions (\(h_{ij}(r)\)).

\[G_{ij}^R = \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 h_{ij}(r) dr\]
Returns:

KBI in units of nm3 and cm3/mol.

kbi_thermo_limit(L, rkbi, min_L_idx)[source]¶

Extrapolate KBI to the thermodynamic limit.

Parameters:

  • L (np.array) – fraction of linear dimension of box volume

  • rkbi (np.array) – KBI as a function of r in RDF, i.e., running KBI

  • min_L_idx (float) – lower bound of L for extrapolation

\[\lambda G_{ij}^R = \lambda G_{ij}^{\infty} + F_{ij}^{\infty}\]
Returns:

list[\(G_{ij}^{\infty}\), \(F_{ij}^{\infty}\)]

property z¶

Mol fraction array (\(z\)) with elements, \(x_i\).

\[x_i = \frac{N_i}{\sum_j N_j}\]
Returns:

mol fraction array, with shape(\(len(\text{systems}) \times n\))

property v¶

Volume fraction array (\(v\)) with elements, \(\phi_i\) where \(V_i\) is molar volume of molecule of type i.

\[\phi_i = \frac{x_i V_i}{\sum_j x_j V_j}\]
Returns:

volume fraction array, with shape(\(len(\text{systems}) \times n\))

G_matrix()[source]¶

Construct a symmetric matrix (\(\textbf{G}\)) of KBI values in the thermodynamic limit

\[\begin{split}\textbf{G} = \begin{bmatrix} G_{11}^\infty & G_{12}^\infty & \cdots & G_{1n}^\infty \\ G_{21}^\infty & G_{22}^\infty & \cdots & G_{2n}^\infty \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ G_{n1}^\infty & G_{n2}^\infty & \cdots & G_{nn}^\infty \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]

where \(G_{ij}^\infty\) is the KBI in the thermodynamic limit in nm3 between molecules of type i and j, with \(G_{ij}^\infty = G_{ji}^\infty\).

return:

np.array of KBI values for each pairwise interaction, with \(shape(\textbf{G}) = len(\text{systems}) \times n \times n\)

B_matrix()[source]¶

Construct a symmetric matrix (\(\textbf{B}\)) of number fluctuations from KBI values in \(\textbf{G}\), with elements \(\textbf{B}_{ij}\).

\[\textbf{B}_{ij} = \rho_i \rho_j \textbf{G}_{ij} + \rho_i \delta_{ij}\]
\[\begin{split}\textbf{B} = \begin{bmatrix} \rho_1^2 \textbf{G}_{11} + \rho_1 & \rho_1 \rho_2 \textbf{G}_{12} & \cdots & \rho_1 \rho_n \textbf{G}_{1n} \\ \rho_1 \rho_2 \textbf{G}_{21} & \rho_2^2 \textbf{G}_{22} + \rho_2 & \cdots & \rho_2 \rho_n \textbf{G}_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \rho_1 \rho_n \textbf{G}_{n1} & \rho_2 \rho_n \textbf{G}_{n2} & \cdots & \rho_n^2 \textbf{G}_{nn} + \rho_n \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]
Returns:

np.array with \(shape(\textbf{B}) = len(\text{systems}) \times n \times n\)

cofactors_Bij()[source]¶

Get the cofactors of \(\textbf{B}\), where elements are defined by \(\textbf{B}^{ij}\).

\[\textbf{B}^{ij} = \left(|\textbf{B}| \textbf{B}^{-1}\right)_{ij}\]
Returns:

cofactor matrix with shape, \(len(\text{systems}) \times n \times n\)

dmu_dN()[source]¶

Calculate derivative of chemical potential with respect to number of molecules of type i

\[\left(\frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial N_j}\right)_{N, p, T} = \frac{k_bT}{\left<V\right> |\textbf{B}|}\left(\frac{\sum_{a=1}^N\sum_{b=1}^N \rho_a\rho_b\left|\textbf{B}^{ij}\textbf{B}^{ab}-\textbf{B}^{ai}\textbf{B}^{bj}\right|}{\sum_{a=1}^N\sum_{b=1}^N \rho_a\rho_b \textbf{B}^{ab}}\right)\]
Returns:

np.array of shape, \(len(\text{systems}) \times n \times n\)

dmu_dxs()[source]¶

Calculate the chemical potential derivative with respect to mol fraction of each component.

\[\left(\frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial x_j}\right) = N \left(\frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial N_j} - \frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial N_n}\right) \]
Returns:

np.array of shape, \(len(\text{systems}) \times n-1 \times n-1\)

dlngamma_dxs()[source]¶

Calculate the activity coefficient derivative with respect to mol fraction of molecule of type i

\[\frac{\partial \gamma_i}{\partial x_i} = \frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial x_i} - \frac{1}{x_i}\]
Returns:

np.array of shape, \(len(\text{systems}) \times n\)

gammas()[source]¶

Numerical integration of activity coefficient derivatives.

\[\ln{\gamma_i}(x_i) = \sum_{a_0}^{x_i} \frac{\Delta x}{2} \left[\left(\frac{\partial \ln{\gamma_i}}{\partial x_i}\right)_{a_0} + \left(\frac{\partial \ln{\gamma_i}}{\partial x_i}\right)_{a_1}\right]\]

where \(a_0\) is the reference state with \(a_0 = 1\) for pure component and \(a_0 = 0\) for infinite dilution. For \(a_0 = 1\), \(a_1 = a_0 - \Delta x\) and for \(a_0 = 0\), \(a_1 = a_0 + \Delta x\).

Returns:

np.array of activity coefficients as a function of composition for each component

GE()[source]¶

Excess Gibbs energy.

\[G^E = RT\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \ln{\gamma_i}\right)\]
Returns:

1D np.array for excess Gibbs energy as a function of composition

GM()[source]¶

Gibbs mixing free energy.

\[\Delta G_{mix} = RT\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \ln{\left(\gamma_i x_i\right)}\right)\]
Returns:

1D np.array for Gibbs mixing free energy as a function of composition

Hmix()[source]¶

Mixing enthalpy from molecular simulation.

\[\Delta H_{mix} = H - \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i H_{i}^{pc} \label{eqn:Hmix}\]

where \(H\) is the enthalpy for a simulation at a given composition and \(H_i^{pc}\) is the pure component enthalpy for molecule of type i.

Returns:

1D np.array for enthalpy as a function of composition

SE()[source]¶

Excess entropy from Gibbs excess property relations.

\[S^E = \frac{\Delta H_{mix} - G^E}{T}\]
Returns:

1D np.array for excess entropy as a function of composition
